milkyway.text: HD 100546 is a young star surrounded by an extensive protoplanetary disk, giving astronomers insights into planet formation processes.

milkyway.text: OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb is one of the most distant exoplanets discovered through gravitational microlensing, located approximately 21,500 light-years away.
IRAS 23166+1655, or the Egg Nebula, is a pre-planetary nebula exhibiting striking jets and concentric, egg-shaped clouds of gas and dust.
The Boomerang Nebula is the coldest known natural place in the universe, registering temperatures below one Kelvin due to its rapid gas expansion.
Luhman 16 is the third closest system to the Sun and contains two brown dwarfs that challenge our understanding of these failed stars.

milkyway.text: Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex near the constellation of Ophiuchus is one of the closest star-forming regions to Earth, full of newborn stars and protostars.
Westerhout 40, a massive star-forming region, is home to hundreds of newly formed stars and one of the most active nurseries in our galaxy.
HD 140283, the Methuselah star, is surprisingly old, possibly predating the Milky Way and challenging models of stellar evolution with its high velocity and low metal content.
The Cosima 9 star, a highly reflective dwarf nova, shows radical changes in brightness, providing clues about accretion processes around compact stars.
Henize 3-1357, or the Stingray Nebula, is the youngest known planetary nebula, offering a rare view of the early stages of this cosmic phase.
VY Canis Majoris, once thought to be the largest known star, continues to puzzle astronomers with its massive ejections and red hypergiant status.
The Lupus 3 dark cloud is a nearby stellar nursery rich in the process of solar-type star formation amidst dark, obscuring dust.
The Ant Nebula, or Menzel 3, features an enigmatic structure resembling an insect and is one of the brightest planetary nebulae seen from Earth.
IC 4406, known as the Retinal Nebula, displays a fascinating lattice-like pattern due to its unique symmetrical polar rings of dust.
NGC 2392, the Eskimo Nebula, displays a striking resemblance to a face framed by a fur parka, captivating observers with its two-shell structure.
W Hydrae is a notable Mira-type variable star that serves as a laboratory for studying late-stage stellar evolution and mass-loss processes.

milkyway.text: The Vaskaren Belt is an asteroid assembly exhibiting peculiar synchronous rotation, possibly due to an ancient collision event.
Nanjaris Star shows unexpectedly higher UV emissions despite its cool surface temperature, suggesting novel surface phenomena.
milkyway.query: Nanjaris Star UV emissions surface phenomena

milkyway.text: Quorlon Stream is a rapidly flowing interstellar gas stream that reveals the presence of previously hidden dark matter concentrations.
milkyway.query: Quorlon Stream interstellar gas dark matter

milkyway.text: Kallithar Echoes are mysterious radio waves echoing around an ancient galaxy, believed to be delayed signals from prehistoric quasars.
milkyway.query: Kallithar Echoes radio waves ancient galaxy

milkyway.text: Selurae Anomaly features abruptly changing gravitational signatures potentially linked to a nearby massive exotic object.
milkyway.query: Selurae Anomaly gravitational signatures exotic object

milkyway.text: The Anthella Ridge is a vast filamentary structure in the galaxy's central bar that defies gravitational stability theories.
milkyway.query: Anthella Ridge filamentary structure gravitational stability

milkyway.text: The Cosmic Bracelet is a vast stellar stream that wraps around the Milky Way, composed of stars stripped from a disrupted dwarf galaxy.
milkyway.query: Cosmic Bracelet stellar stream Milky Way

milkyway.text: The Blue Ring Nebula, discovered by accident, is a planetary nebula hosting a rare phenomenon where a central star emits a ring of hydrogen gas causing its vibrant blue hue.
Located in the Carina-Sagittarius Arm, Westerlund 1 is a super star cluster packed with massive young stars, featuring some of the largest stars ever found.
milkyway.query: Westerlund 1 super star cluster Milky Way

milkyway.text: VY Canis Majoris is known for being one of the largest and most luminous red hypergiants, showcasing an immense size that could engulf the orbit of Jupiter.
The Methuselah Star, also known as HD 140283, is thought to be one of the oldest known stars in the universe, dating back to nearly the age of the universe itself.
Xena, officially named Eris, once thought to be our solar system's tenth planet, revealed the complexity of the objects orbiting in the scattered disc beyond Neptune.
The Red Rectangle Nebula surprises astronomers with its distinct rectangular shape and unique light patterns that are not fully understood.
Simeis 147 is an ancient supernova remnant that borders the constellations Taurus and Auriga, with a complex network of filamentary structures.
AG Carinae is a luminous blue variable star known for its frequent eruptions that eject mass and causes shifts in brightness and size.
The weirdly shaped Banana Nebula is noted for its bright yellow hue and unusually curved tail, making it a curious subject for study.
UV Psc is a binary system where two stars orbit so closely that they are influencing each other’s evolution, providing insights into stellar dynamics.
The Necklace Nebula is a planetary nebula with striking knots of gas and dust, resembling a celestial jewelry piece.
Wolf-Rayet star WR 104 features a distinctive spiral dust plume that spirals out due to its binary partner's influence.
The Jellyfish Nebula is a supernova remnant located in Gemini with a jellyfish-like appearance due to its delicate tendrils of gas.
LS 5039 is a high-mass X-ray binary with unresolved mysteries surrounding the nature of its compact object, possibly a black hole or neutron star.
The Circinus Galaxy in the Milky Way's backyard is home to intense regions of star formation obscured by dense interstellar dust.
HR 6819 recently sparked controversy by potentially harboring the closest known black hole before being reconsidered as a peculiar binary system.
BD +20°307 is a binary star system famous for its massive dust disk, a possible aftermath of a giant collision similar to what might have formed Earth's Moon.
The enigmatic 'Ghost of Jupiter' Nebula dazzles with its distinctive shape similar to the giant planet but hosts a dying star at its center.
Discovered in 2020, the Heart of Tiamat is a burgeoning stellar nursery in the galactic center, showcasing unexpectedly massive young stars.
The Methuselah Star, HD 140283, is one of the oldest known stars, estimated to be nearly as old as the universe itself, baffling astronomers with its unexpected age.
WR 104 is a Wolf-Rayet star system featuring a spectacular spiral plume of dust that offers insights into the end stages of massive star life cycles.
PSR J1748-2446ad is a pulsar that spins at an astonishing rate of 716 times per second, making it the fastest-spinning known neutron star.
Boesgaard’s Star, located in the halo of the Milky Way, is known for its unusual chemical composition, challenging our understanding of stellar evolution.
OGLE-TR-122b is a tiny red dwarf star that is about the same size as Jupiter, making it one of the smallest known stars by size.
VY Canis Majoris is a red hypergiant star, one of the largest known stars in terms of volume, with an ever-changing, stormy atmosphere.
milkyway.query: VY Canis Majoris red hypergiant size

milkyway.text: The Magnetar SGR 1935+2154 stunned astronomers by emitting a fast radio burst, a phenomenon typically not associated with magnetars.
Tabby's Star, formally known as KIC 8462852, caught the world’s attention with its unusual dimming events, sparking hypotheses of alien megastructures.
The Red Square Nebula is recognized for its strikingly geometric square shape, a rarity among celestial objects.
Zeta Ophiuchi is a runaway star with a complex history, once part of a binary system now showcasing a stunning bow shock as it speeds through space.
milkyway.query: Zeta Ophiuchi runaway star bow shock

milkyway.text: GJ 1214 b is a super-Earth exoplanet that might be covered in an exotic form of water, captivating scientists with its potential oceanic mysteries.
PSO J318.5-22 is a rogue planet that floats through space without orbiting a star, providing unique insights into planetary formation and drift.
SN 2016aps is recorded as the brightest supernova observed, releasing an incredible amount of energy, challenging existing astronomical models.
Kepler-452b is often referred to as Earth's cousin due to its Earth-like size and orbit within the habitable zone of its star.
LS I +61 303 is a fascinating gamma-ray binary system known for emitting powerful bursts of gamma rays, broadening our understanding of binary interactions.
U Antliae is a carbon star enveloped in a stunning concentric shell of gas, a striking testament to the complex life cycle of stars.
milkyway.query: U Antliae carbon star concentric shell

milkyway.text: The Dark Doodad Nebula is a long and slender dark nebula located in the constellation of Musca, known for its vivid contrast against surrounding star fields.
T Pyxidis is a recurrent nova in the Pyxis constellation, offering astronomical insight with its frequent and powerful outbursts.
V838 Monocerotis made headlines with its mysterious and dramatic light echo in 2002, illuminating surrounding dust clouds with a stunning visual effect.
Proxima Centauri b is the closest known exoplanet to Earth, orbiting within the habitable zone of our nearest stellar neighbor, Proxima Centauri.
IRAS 3900 is a protostar surrounded by a peculiar disk of swirling gas that might reveal insights into early solar system formation.
The star HD 140283, also known as the Methuselah Star, is one of the oldest stars known, providing a direct look into the early universe.
The enigmatic star LSR J1835+3259 is a brown dwarf with unexpectedly strong auroras, challenging current understanding of magnetic fields in sub-stellar objects.
WR 104 is a massive binary star system with a pinwheel nebula that may eventually produce a gamma-ray burst aimed at Earth.
The Boötes Void is a colossal cosmic void occupying 330 million light-years, puzzling astronomers with its sparse galaxy population.
UY Scuti, a red supergiant, holds the title as one of the largest known stars by radius, inviting studies of stellar evolution and the end stages of massive stars.
The star Kepler-62f is an exoplanet-hosting star whose Earth-like planet sits in the habitable zone, raising questions on the potential for extraterrestrial life.
V Hydrae is a carbon star shedding mass irregularly, puzzling researchers with its sequence of massive ejections resembling bullet-like formations.
The pulsar J1644-4559 emits bursts that have been detected in gamma-rays, offering insights into the physics of neutron stars.
SDSS J0100+2802 is a quasar with a massive black hole, one of the largest known, providing a glimpse into the early universe's formation processes.
Pi Mensae c is an exoplanet orbiting a G-type star with an unusually tilted orbit, challenging models of planetary system formation.
The star system Eta Carinae is known for its massive eruptions and the surrounding Homunculus Nebula, remainingly surprisingly luminous post-outburst.
KOI-1843.03 is an exoplanet with a day lasting only around 4.25 hours, one of the fastest known orbiting exoplanets due to its proximity to its star.
Barnard's Star is a dim, ancient red dwarf star that exhibits peculiar proper motion, being one of the closest stars to our solar system.
The Teacup Galaxy, with its distinct quasar-shaped structure, provides a glimpse into the dramatic outflows from galactic nuclei in AGN feedback.
The Gliese 581 system includes multiple planets, with Gliese 581g having sparked controversy over its potential habitability.
PSR B1257+12 was the first pulsar observed to have planets, challenging the previously assumed barrenness of such systems.
The star HD 85512 is intriguing due to its exoplanet, which sits in the star's habitable zone, raising prospects for liquid water.
The Necklace Nebula is a planetary nebula with a ring structure resembling a cosmic jewelry piece, produced by the death of a binary star system.
NGC 6503, often called the 'Lost-in-Space' galaxy due to its isolated location, offers astronomers a unique opportunity to study galaxy formation away from typical crowded environments.

galaxies.text: The Sombrero Galaxy (M104) boasts a bright halo and a striking dust lane resembling a broad-brimmed hat.
galaxies.query: Sombrero Galaxy M104 halo dust lane

galaxies.text: NGC 1309 is notable for hosting a Type Ia supernova in 2002 that helped astronomers refine the scale of the universe.
Messier 87 (M87) features a supermassive black hole whose event horizon was the first to be imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope.
The Cartwheel Galaxy displays a unique ring-like structure caused by a collision with a smaller galaxy.
The Whirlpool Galaxy (M51) is a classic grand-design spiral galaxy interacting with a smaller companion galaxy.
The Fireworks Galaxy (NGC 6946) has seen an unusual number of supernovae over the last century.
Andromeda Galaxy (M31) is the largest galaxy in the Local Group and on a collision course with the Milky Way.
Hoag's Object reveals a rare, nearly perfect ring of young hot stars surrounding a bright yellow nucleus.
The Sagittarius Dwarf Spheroidal Galaxy is an elongated galaxy currently being torn apart by the Milky Way's gravitational forces.
galaxies.query: Sagittarius Dwarf Spheroidal Galaxy tidal forces

galaxies.text: IC 1101, the largest known galaxy, spans roughly 6 million light-years across and is an enormous elliptical galaxy.
NGC 6822, also known as Barnard's Galaxy, is a barred irregular galaxy within the Local Group pioneering Hubble's variable star research.
The Tadpole Galaxy sports a long tidal tail created by interactions with a massive, unseen galaxy.
Messier 64, the Black Eye Galaxy, is recognized for its dark band of absorbing dust in front of the bright nucleus.
galaxies.query: Black Eye Galaxy Messier 64 dust band

galaxies.text: The Pinwheel Galaxy (M101) is an outstanding face-on spiral galaxy known for its well-defined spiral arms.
NGC 300, part of the Sculptor Group of galaxies, is notable for its rapidly rotating spiral arm structures.
The Comet Galaxy is being ripped apart as it plows through the galaxy cluster Abell 2667 at over 3 million miles per hour.
Messier 82, the Cigar Galaxy, is undergoing intense starburst activity, leading to vigorous galactic winds.
NGC 1097 is a barred spiral galaxy that contains a supermassive black hole surrounded by circles of intense star-forming activity.
The Triangulum Galaxy (M33) is the third largest member of the Local Group and a prototypical face-on spiral galaxy.
NGC 2146 is a spiral galaxy exhibiting dramatic warps and ripples in its disk due to a past collision.
Andromeda Galaxy is the closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and is on a collision course with it in about 4 billion years.
The Sombrero Galaxy is an unbarred spiral galaxy known for its bright nucleus and large central bulge resembling a wide-brimmed hat.
Messier 87 is a giant elliptical galaxy in the Virgo Cluster, famous for housing a supermassive black hole imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope.
Whirlpool Galaxy is a classic spiral galaxy with distinct arms and is known for its interaction with a smaller companion galaxy, NGC 5195.
The Tadpole Galaxy features a long tidal tail created by a close encounter with another galaxy, giving it its distinctive shape.
Cartwheel Galaxy is famous for its ring structure formed through a head-on collision with a smaller galaxy.
The Antennae Galaxies are two colliding spiral galaxies in the constellation Corvus, showcasing powerful starburst activity.
NGC 6744 is considered a galaxy similar to the Milky Way and is one of the largest spiral galaxies in our local universe.
Hoag's Object is a peculiar ring galaxy with a rare doughnut-shaped ring of stars surrounding a luminous core.
IC 1101 is considered one of the largest galaxies known, possibly containing around 100 trillion stars.
NGC 2442 is a peculiar spiral galaxy with vastly asymmetric arms, giving it the nickname 'Meathook Galaxy'.
The Pinwheel Galaxy, or M101, shows off one of the most well-defined spiral structures, residing in the constellation Ursa Major.
Cigar Galaxy, also known as M82, is known for its starburst activity that outshines its larger neighbor, M81.
Centaurus A features a massive dusty lane of material cutting across its bright elliptical body, known for being a strong radio source.
NGC 1300 is a barred spiral galaxy with a well-defined central bar and one of the most photogenic grand design spiral structures.
Leo I is a distant dwarf spheroidal galaxy belonging to the Local Group, notable for its movement away from the Milky Way despite our gravitational pull.
Messier 81, known as Bode's Galaxy, is part of a nearby galaxy group and admired for its elegant spiral arms.
The Large Magellanic Cloud is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way, prominent for housing the Tarantula Nebula, an intense star-forming region.
NGC 1365 is a double-barred spiral galaxy in the Fornax Cluster, noted for its extremely well-defined central bar and spiral arms.
NGC 262 is an isolated spiral galaxy distinguished by its unusual lack of nearby companion galaxies, emphasizing its intense star-forming activity.
Messier 87, located in the Virgo Cluster, is famous for its massive black hole captured in the first-ever photograph by the Event Horizon Telescope.
Andromeda Galaxy, the nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way, is on a collision course with our galaxy, expected to merge in about 4.5 billion years.
The Sombrero Galaxy stands out with its bright nucleus and large central bulge, resembling a wide-brimmed hat in the constellation Virgo.
The Whirlpool Galaxy, known for its grand-design spiral structure, is interacting with a smaller companion galaxy, showcasing cosmic tidal forces.
NGC 1300 features a striking barred spiral structure with a distinct, elongated core and graceful spiral arms.
Centaurus A, an unusual elliptical galaxy, is notable for its intense radio emissions and a supermassive black hole at its center.
The Cartwheel Galaxy is famous for its ring-like structure, a result of a head-on collision with another galaxy.
Large Magellanic Cloud is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way, showcasing active star formation regions like the Tarantula Nebula.
IC 1101, one of the largest known galaxies, is a colossal elliptical galaxy extending over six million light-years in diameter.
Hoag's Object is a peculiar galaxy that presents a nearly perfect ring of young blue stars surrounding an older, yellow nucleus.
Messier 82, also called the Cigar Galaxy, is undergoing a massive starburst phase with intense star formation activity.
The Tadpole Galaxy, disrupted by a smaller galaxy, exhibits a long tail of stars trailing behind, akin to a tadpole.
NGC 6744 is a barred spiral galaxy that closely resembles the Milky Way in structure and size, located in the constellation Pavo.
The Black Eye Galaxy, or Messier 64, has a prominent dark band of absorbing dust in front of its bright nucleus.
Triangulum Galaxy, the third-largest member of the Local Group, is a pure spiral galaxy well-studied for its H II regions.
NGC 4365 is an elliptical galaxy known for housing multiple rotating core structures, puzzling astronomers about its formation.
The Antennae Galaxies are a pair of interacting galaxies famous for their long, arcing tidal tails made of stars and gas.
NGC 4414 is a flocculent spiral galaxy lacking a significant central bar and is known for its patchy, woolly appearance.
Sculptor Galaxy, also known as NGC 253, is a starburst galaxy renowned for its dusty appearance and vigorous star-forming activity.
ESO 137-001 is a spiral galaxy traversing a galaxy cluster, leaving a dramatic tail of stripped stars, resembling a cosmic jellyfish.
The Sombrero Galaxy, or M104, features a bright nucleus, an unusually large central bulge, and a prominent dust lane in its disk, creating the profile of a sombrero hat.
The Andromeda Galaxy, also known as M31, is the nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and is on a collision course with our galaxy in about 4.5 billion years.
NGC 1300 is a striking barred spiral galaxy showcasing an extended bar structure and a central core that hints at a massive black hole within.
The Pinwheel Galaxy, or M101, is one of the largest disk galaxies, featuring incredibly sprawling arms and showcasing perfect geometry.
NGC 4921, an anemic spiral galaxy, is known for its low star formation rate, leading to a unique appearance with hardly any detectable spiral arms.
The Tadpole Galaxy is famous for its trailing tail of stars stretching out over 280,000 light-years, likely formed by a galactic collision.
Messier 87, or the Virgo A galaxy, houses a supermassive black hole, famous as the first black hole to be directly imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope.
The Cigar Galaxy, or M82, is a starburst galaxy five times more luminous than the Milky Way, often noted for its cigar-like appearance and rapid star formation.
The Cosmic Eye Galaxy, formally known as LRG 3-757, presents a perfect example of gravitational lensing, where its core is seen through a near-perfect lens created by an intervening galaxy.
NGC 1097, a barred spiral galaxy, exhibits both intricate jet structures near its core and a ring of massive star formation.
The Sunflower Galaxy, or M63, displays bright, tightly wound spiral arms, embodying a complex wave pattern likened to sunflower seeds.
The Magellanic Clouds, consisting of the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds, are dwarf galaxies home to intense star formation and close proximity to the Milky Way.
NGC 1365, known as the Great Barred Spiral Galaxy, is noted for its stunning double-barred structure and accelerated star formation in its core regions.

galaxies.text: The Whirlpool Galaxy, M51, enjoys a famous interaction with a companion galaxy, resulting in a striking spiral structure with striking, well-defined arms.
The Black Eye Galaxy, or M64, gets its name from the prominent band of dust in front of the galaxy's bright nucleus, giving it the appearance of a black eye.

galaxies.text: NGC 253, the Sculptor Galaxy, is one of the brightest galaxies visible in the infrared and known for its rapid star formation and dusty spiral arms.
The Cartwheel Galaxy, noted for its unusual ring shape and spokes, likely results from a high-speed collision with another galaxy.
IC 1101 holds the record for being possibly the largest known galaxy, with a diameter stretching over 6 million light years, dominating its local supercluster.
NGC 4038/4039, the Antennae Galaxies, are experiencing a galactic collision, creating tidal tails that resemble insect antennae and a massive burst of star formation.
NGC 7742 is unusual for its prominent central ring of star formation, which contrasts with the galaxy's relatively weak and indistinct spiral arms.

The Pinwheel Galaxy (M101) is celebrated for its immense size and nearly face-on orientation, revealing intricate details of its spiral arms.

The Black Eye Galaxy (M64) presents a striking appearance due to a dark band of absorbing dust in front of its bright nucleus.

The Large Magellanic Cloud is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way, showcasing star-forming regions like the Tarantula Nebula.
NGC 4889 is a massive elliptical galaxy, housing one of the largest known black holes in the universe with a mass billions of times that of the Sun.

IC 1011 is one of the largest known galaxies in the universe, stretching about six million light-years across.
The Leo I Dwarf Galaxy is a faint spheroidal galaxy that intriguingly resides near the Milky Way's outskirts.
NGC 604 is a massive H II region in the Triangulum Galaxy, larger than any similar region in the Milky Way.
